{{hatnote|For the documentary, see [[Kids for Cash]].}} [[File:LuzerneCountyCourthouseRiverCommons.jpg|{{largethumb}}|alt=An image showing the large domed Luzerne County Courthouse in Wilkes-Barre as seen from across the Susquehanna River|Luzerne County Courthouse in [[Wilkes-Barre]], Pennsylvania]]
The '''"kids for cash" scandal''' centered on judicial [[Kickback (bribery)|kickbacks]] to two judges at the [[Luzerne County, Pennsylvania|Luzerne County]] [[Pennsylvania courts of common pleas|Court of Common Pleas]] in [[Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania]].<ref name="RedFlagsNYT">{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/28/us/28judges.html |title=Despite Red Flags, Judges Ran Kickback Scheme for Years |last=Urbina |first=Ian |date=March 27, 2009 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=January 25, 2018}}</ref> In 2008, judges [[Michael Conahan]] and [[Mark Ciavarella]] were accused of accepting money in return for imposing harsh [[adjudication]]s on juveniles to increase occupancy at for-profit detention centers.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www2.ca3.uscourts.gov/opinarch/113277p.pdf |title=United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit No. 11-3277: United States of America v. Mark Ciavarella, Jr., Appellant |date=May 24, 2013 |website=United States Courts |access-date=January 25, 2018}}</ref>
Ciavarella disposed thousands of children to extended stays in youth centers for offenses as trivial as mocking an assistant principal on [[Myspace]] or [[trespass]]ing in a vacant building.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2009/CRIME/02/23/pennsylvania.corrupt.judges/ |title=Pennsylvania rocked by 'jailing kids for cash' scandal |last=Chen |first=Stephanie |date=February 23, 2009 |website=CNN |access-date=January 25, 2018}}</ref> After a judge rejected an initial [[Plea bargain|plea agreement]] in 2009,<ref name="doj-charges">{{cite web |url=http://www.usdoj.gov/usao/pam/press_releases/Ciavarella_Conahan_01_26_09.htm |title=Federal Officials Announce the Filing of Federal Fraud and Tax Charges Against Two Luzerne County Common Pleas Courts Judges in an On-going Public Corruption Probe |date=January 26, 2009 |website=U.S. Department of Justice |access-date=January 25, 2018 |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090901151339/http://www.usdoj.gov/usao/pam/press_releases/Ciavarella_Conahan_01_26_09.htm |archive-date=September 1, 2009}}</ref><ref name="kosik-memo">{{cite news |url=http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/pdf/national/20090801_judges_memorandum.pdf |title=Memorandum and Order, United States District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania |last=Kosik |first=Edwin |date=July 30, 2009 |newspaper=The New York Times |access-date=September 14, 2018}}</ref> a [[Grand juries in the United States|federal grand jury]] returned a 48-count [[indictment]].<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.timesleader.com/archive/264043/stories-ex-judges-hit-with-48-counts118222 |title=Ex-judges hit with 48 counts |last=Morgan-Besecker |first=Terrie |date=September 10, 2009 |newspaper=[[Times Leader]] |access-date=January 25, 2018}}</ref> In 2010, Conahan pleaded guilty to one count of [[Racket (crime)|racketeering conspiracy]] and was sentenced to 17.5 years in [[federal prison]].<ref name="conahan-sentenced">{{Cite news |url=http://thetimes-tribune.com/news/former-luzerne-judge-conahan-sentenced-to-17-5-years-1.1207994 |title=Former Luzerne judge Conahan sentenced to 17.5 years |date=September 23, 2011 |newspaper=[[The Scranton Times-Tribune]] |access-date=January 25, 2018 |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110925034428/http://thetimes-tribune.com/news/former-luzerne-judge-conahan-sentenced-to-17-5-years-1.1207994 |archive-date=September 25, 2011}}</ref> Ciavarella opted to go to trial the following year. He was convicted on 12 of 39 counts and sentenced to 28 years in federal prison.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/44105072/ns/us_news-crime_and_courts/t/pennsylvania-judge-gets-years-kids-cash-case/ |title=Pennsylvania judge gets 28 years in 'kids for cash' case |date=August 11, 2011 |website=NBC News |access-date=January 25, 2018}}</ref>
In the wake of the scandal, the [[Supreme Court of Pennsylvania]] overturned hundreds of adjudications of delinquency in Luzerne County.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2009/03/26/national/main4895883.shtml |title=Court Tosses Convictions of Corrupt Judge |agency=Associated Press |date=March 26, 2009 |website=CBS News |access-date=January 25, 2018}}</ref> The [[Juvenile Law Center]] filed a [[Class action|class action lawsuit]] against the judges and numerous other parties,<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://jlc.org/legal-docket/ht-et-al-v-mark-ciavarella-jr-et-al |title=H.T. et al. v. Mark A. Ciavarella, Jr., et al. |website=[[Juvenile Law Center]] |access-date=January 25, 2018}}</ref> and the [[Pennsylvania General Assembly|Pennsylvania state legislature]] created a commission to investigate juvenile justice problems in the county.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.prnewswire.com/DisplayReleaseContent.aspx?ACCT=ind_focus.story&STORY=/www/story/08-07-2009/0005074011&EDATE= |title=Governor Rendell Signs Bill Creating Commission to Probe Juvenile Justice System |date=August 7, 2009 |website=[[PR Newswire]] |access-date=January 25, 2018 |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090902182032/http://news.prnewswire.com/DisplayReleaseContent.aspx?ACCT=ind_focus.story&STORY=%2Fwww%2Fstory%2F08-07-2009%2F0005074011&EDATE= |archive-date=2009-09-02 |df= }}</ref>
== Investigations == The Pennsylvania state Judicial Conduct Board received four complaints about Conahan between 2004 and 2008, but later admitted it failed to investigate any of them, nor had it sought documentation regarding the cases involved.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://jjie.org/2010/03/22/getting-the-juvenile-justice-system-to-grow-up/18/ |title=State Failed to Investigate Complaints in Juvenile Court Kickback Scandal |last=Echols |first=Noah |date=March 22, 2010 |website=Juvenile Justice Information Exchange |access-date=December 7, 2016}}</ref> The FBI was tipped off about Conahan and [[nepotism]] in the county courts in 2006.<ref name="conduct-board">{{cite news |url=http://citizensvoice.com/news/lokuta-says-conduct-board-kept-conahan-allegations-under-wraps-1.480057 |title=Lokuta says conduct board kept Conahan allegations under wraps |last=Sisak |first=Michael R. |date=December 12, 2009 |newspaper=[[The Citizens' Voice]] |access-date=December 7, 2016 |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091214020749/http://citizensvoice.com/news/lokuta-says-conduct-board-kept-conahan-allegations-under-wraps-1.480057 |archive-date=December 14, 2009}}</ref> An additional investigation into improper sentencing in Luzerne County began early in 2007 as a result of requests for assistance from several youths received by the [[Philadelphia]]-based Juvenile Law Center. Attorneys from the center determined that several hundred cases were tried without the defendants receiving proper counsel. In April 2008, the Center petitioned the [[Pennsylvania Supreme Court]] seeking relief for alleged violation of the youths' [[civil rights]]. The application of relief was later denied, then reconsidered in January 2009 when charges of corruption against the judges surfaced.<ref name="jlc-luzerne">{{cite web |url=http://www.jlc.org/luzerne/ |title=Luzerne County |date=April 27, 2009 |website=Juvenile Law Center |access-date=May 2, 2009 |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100412100902/http://www.jlc.org/luzerne/ |archive-date=April 12, 2010}}</ref>
The [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] and the [[Internal Revenue Service]] also investigated the two judges, although the exact dates and scope of the investigations by the two federal agencies were not made public.<ref name="hall-summary"/> Part of the investigation was revealed to have occurred during disciplinary hearings over the conduct of another former Luzerne County judge, Ann H. Lokuta.<ref name="plw-lokuta">{{cite journal |url=http://www.palawweekly.com/getarticle.aspx?id=28264 |title=Rumors Intensify About Investigation Into Allegations of Luzerne County Case-Fixing |first1=Leo |last1=Strupczewski |first2=Peter |last2=Hall |date=February 9, 2009 |journal=Pennsylvania Law Weekly |accessdate=August 27, 2009}}</ref> Lokuta was brought before the Judicial Conduct Board of Pennsylvania in November 2006 to answer charges of using court workers to do her personal bidding, openly displaying bias against some attorneys arguing before her, and publicly berating staff to cause mental distress.<ref name="morgan-lokuta1">{{cite news |url=http://www.timesleader.com/news/hottopics/judges/Board__Lokuta_violated_ethics_10-31-2008.html |title=Board: Lokuta violated ethics |last=Morgan-Besecker |first=Terrie |date=November 5, 2008 |newspaper=Times Leader |accessdate=August 27, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090901151153/http://www.timesleader.com/news/hottopics/judges/Board__Lokuta_violated_ethics_10-31-2008.html |archivedate=September 1, 2009}}</ref> The board ruled against Lokuta in November 2008, and she was removed from the bench. During the course of the disciplinary hearings, Lokuta accused Conahan of bullying behavior and charged that he was behind a conspiracy to have her removed.<ref name="morgan-lokuta-conspiracy">{{cite news |url=http://www.timesleader.com/news/hottopics/judges/Witnesses_back_Lokuta_claim_of_conspiracy_08-08-2009.html |title=Witnesses back Lokuta claim of conspiracy |last=Morgan-Besecker |first=Terrie |date=August 8, 2009 |newspaper=Times Leader |accessdate=August 27, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090812115041/http://www.timesleader.com/news/hottopics/judges/Witnesses_back_Lokuta_claim_of_conspiracy_08-08-2009.html |archivedate=August 12, 2009}}</ref> Lokuta aided the federal investigation into the "kids for cash" scheme prior to the determination of the disciplinary board, and a stay order was issued in March 2009 by the state Supreme Court in light of the ongoing corruption investigations, halting Lokuta's removal and the election that was to be held in May to replace her.<ref name="morgan-lokuta-stay">{{cite news |url=http://www.timesleader.com/news/hottopics/judges/Ruling__Keep_Lokuta_seat_off_ballot_03-26-2009.html |title=Ruling: Keep Lokuta seat off ballot |last=Morgan-Besecker |first=Terrie |date=March 26, 2009 |newspaper=Times Leader |accessdate=August 27, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090901150911/http://www.timesleader.com/news/hottopics/judges/Ruling__Keep_Lokuta_seat_off_ballot_03-26-2009.html |archivedate=September 1, 2009}}</ref> During the Lokuta hearing, Conahan testified that there were no social relationships amongst the county judges. However, Judge Michael Toole, who was later convicted of case fixing, as well as another judge, had each stayed at a Florida condo jointly owned by Conahan and Ciavarella.<ref name="conduct-board"/> The state Supreme Court decided to uphold Lokuta's removal from the bench in January 2011, finding she had received a fair trial, regardless of Conahan's testimony. It also ordered the [[expungement]]s of the records of 2,401 of those juveniles who were affected.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://citizensvoice.com/news/former-judge-lokuta-still-off-the-bench-1.1090664#axzz1EPvrEfw3 |title=Former judge Lokuta still off the bench |last=Janoski |first=Dave |date=January 15, 2011 |newspaper=The Citizen's Voice |access-date=December 7, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://jjie.org/2013/04/12/prisons-are-no-place-for-profit/ |title=Prisons are no Place for Profit |last=Lash |first=John |date=April 12, 2013 |website=Juvenile Justice Information Exchange |access-date=December 7, 2016}}</ref>
== Charges and pleas == A statement from the office of the [[United States Attorney]] for the Middle District of Pennsylvania outlined the charges against the two judges on January 26, 2009. The charges outlined in the [[Information (formal criminal charge)|information]]<ref name="charges-1-26-09">{{cite web |url=http://www.justice.gov/usao/pam/Corruption/Ciavarella_Conahan/conahan%20and%20ciavarella%20information.pdf |title=United States of America v. Michael T. Conahan and Mark A. Ciavarella, Jr., Defendants |date=January 26, 2009 |website=U.S. Department of Justice for the Middle District of Pennsylvania |accessdate=September 12, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121019024006/http://www.justice.gov/usao/pam/Corruption/Ciavarella_Conahan/conahan%20and%20ciavarella%20information.pdf |archivedate=October 19, 2012}}</ref> described actions between 2000 and 2007 by both judges to assist in the construction and population of private juvenile facilities operated by the two Pennsylvania Child Care companies, acting in an official capacity in favor of the private facilities over the facility operated by Luzerne County.<ref name="hall-summary">{{cite web |url=http://www.law.com/jsp/nlj/PubArticleNLJ.jsp?id=1202427800493&slreturn=1&hbxlogin=1 |title=Judges to Serve More Than Seven Years in Prison After Pleading Guilty in Kickbacks Probe |first1=Peter |last1=Hall |first2=Leo |last2=Strupczewski |date=January 28, 2009 |journal=[[The Legal Intelligencer]] |accessdate=August 26, 2009}}</ref>
The U.S. Attorney charged that in 2002 Conahan, who at the time was President Judge of the court, used his authority to remove funding for the county-operated facility. The judges were alleged to have received "millions of dollars" in payments for the completion of a binding agreement between the court and the private facilities, co-owned by attorney Robert Powell, to use their services and the subsequent closing of the county facility.<ref name="doj-charges" /> The methods used to conceal the payments involved several parties and transactions which resulted in allegations of [[Tax avoidance and tax evasion#Tax evasion|tax evasion]] against the two. Ciavarella and Conahan were also charged with "Ordering juveniles to be sent to these facilities in which the judges had a financial interest even when Juvenile Probation Officers did not recommend placement," according to the statement.<ref name="doj-charges" />
Original, negotiated plea agreements called for both judges to serve up to seven years in prison, pay fines and restitution, and accept responsibility for the crimes.<ref name="RedFlagsNYT"/> However, on July 30, 2009, Judge [[Edwin M. Kosik]] of [[United States District Court for the Middle District of Pennsylvania|Federal District Court]] in nearby [[Scranton, Pennsylvania|Scranton]] rejected the plea agreement, citing "post-guilty plea conduct and expressions from the defendants" that he ruled did not satisfy the terms of the agreement. Kosik wrote that Conahan and Ciavarella continued to deny their crimes even in the face of overwhelming evidence, and therefore did not merit sentences that were well below federal sentencing guidelines.<ref>{{cite news |title=Plea Agreement by 2 Judges Is Rejected In Pennsylvania |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/01/us/01judge.html |last=Urbina |first=Ian |newspaper=The New York Times |date=July 31, 2009 |accessdate=August 27, 2009}}</ref><ref name="kosik-memo"/> Attorneys for the two judges brought a motion requesting reconsideration of the judge's rejection of the plea agreement.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Former Pa. Judges Ask for Reconsideration of Rejected Pleas |url=http://www.law.com/jsp/article.jsp?id=1202433222973&Former_Pa_Judges_Ask_for_Reconsideration_of_Rejected_Pleas |first1=Leo |last1=Strupczewski |first2=Hank |last2=Grezlak |journal=The Legal Intelligencer |date=August 21, 2009 |accessdate=August 27, 2009}}</ref> The motion was denied on August 24, 2009, and Ciavarella and Conahan subsequently withdrew their guilty pleas, an action which eventually resulted in a [[jury trial]] for Ciavarella and additional charges against the former judges.<ref name="morgan-becker1">{{cite news |url=http://www.timesleader.com/news/Judges_withdraw_guilty_pleas_08-25-2009.html |title=Judges withdraw guilty pleas |last=Morgan-Besecker |first=Terrie |date=August 25, 2009 |newspaper=Times Leader |accessdate=August 25, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090901150107/http://www.timesleader.com/news/Judges_withdraw_guilty_pleas_08-25-2009.html |archivedate=September 1, 2009}}</ref>
Following the plea withdrawals, on September 9, 2009, a federal grand jury in Harrisburg, Pennsylvania returned a 48-count indictment<ref name="indictment">{{cite web |url=http://media.theweekender.com/documents/INDICTMENT.pdf |title=Indictment – USA v. Conahan and Ciavarella |date=September 9, 2009 |accessdate=September 12, 2009}}{{dead link |date=November 2012}}</ref> against Ciavarella and Conahan including racketeering, fraud, money laundering, extortion, bribery, and federal tax violations. Both judges were arraigned on the charges on September 15, 2009.<ref name="grand jury">{{cite news |url=http://www.timesleader.com/news/Ex-judges_hit_with_48_counts_09-10-2009.html |title=Ex-judges hit with 48 counts |last=Morgan-Besecker |first=Terrie |date=September 10, 2009 |newspaper=Times Leader |accessdate=September 11, 2009}}</ref><ref name="new release">{{cite web |url=http://www.wbcitizensvoice.com/pdfs/racketeering_release.pdf |title=Two Former Luzerne County Court of Common Pleas Judges Indicted on Racketeering, Fraud, Money Laundering, Tax and Related Charges |date=September 9, 2009 |website=U.S. Attorney's Office, Middle District of Pennsylvania |accessdate=September 10, 2009 |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110304194524/http://www.wbcitizensvoice.com/pdfs/racketeering_release.pdf |archive-date=March 4, 2011}}</ref> Ciavarella and Conahan entered pleas of not guilty on all counts and remained free on $1 million in bail, despite federal prosecutors' contentions that their bail should be raised. Prosecutors argued the judges' bail should have been higher, since they faced the possibility of substantially more prison time and there had been evidence of attempts made to shield assets.<ref name="bail">{{cite news |url=http://www.timesleader.com/news/hottopics/judges/Ex-jurists_plea__still_free_09-16-2009.html |title=Ex-jurists plea, still free Magistrate judge declines to raise bail. Federal prosecutors see Conahan, Ciavarella as flight risks |last=Morgan-Besecker |first=Terrie |date=September 16, 2009 |newspaper=Times Leader |accessdate=October 5, 2009}}</ref>
Robert Powell, an attorney and co-owner of the two juvenile facilities at the heart of the scandal, pleaded guilty on July 1, 2009, to [[Misprision of felony|failing to report a felony]] and being an accessory to tax evasion conspiracy, in connection with $770,000 in kickbacks he paid to Ciavarella and Conahan in exchange for facilitating the development of his juvenile detention centers.<ref name="sisak-powell">{{cite news |url=http://www.thetimes-tribune.com/news/1.99257 |title=Powell pleads guilty |last=Sisak |first=Michael |date=July 1, 2009 |newspaper=The Scranton Times-Tribune |accessdate=August 26, 2009}}</ref><ref name="dale-mericle" /><ref name="doj-powell">{{cite web |title=United States v. Robert Powell |url=http://www.usdoj.gov/usao/pam/Victim_Witness/Luzerne_County_Corruption/Powell/powell_index.html |website=The United States Attorney's Office, Middle District of Pennsylvania |accessdate=August 25, 2009}}</ref> The Pennsylvania Supreme Court temporarily suspended Powell's law license on September 1, citing his criminal conviction.<ref name="suspension">{{cite news |url=http://www.timesleader.com/news/hottopics/judges/Pa__court_suspends_Powell_rsquo_s_law_license_09-02-2009.html |title=Pa. court suspends Powell's law license |last=Lewis |first=Edward |date=September 2, 2009 |newspaper=Times Leader |accessdate=September 6, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120224030545/http://www.timesleader.com/news/hottopics/judges/Pa__court_suspends_Powell_rsquo_s_law_license_09-02-2009.html |archivedate=February 24, 2012}}</ref>
Robert Mericle, the prominent real estate developer who built the two juvenile facilities, pleaded guilty on September 3, 2009, to failing to disclose a felony. Mericle had failed to tell a grand jury he had paid $2.1 million to Ciavarella and Conahan as a finder's fee. As part of his plea, Mericle agreed to pay $2.15 million to fund local children's health and welfare programs. Mericle faced up to three years in prison and a $250,000 maximum fine.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Janoski |first1=Dave |title=Mericle will plead guilty in kids-for-cash scandal |url=http://citizensvoice.com/news/mericle-will-plead-guilty-in-kids-for-cash-scandal-1.183985 |accessdate=11 December 2015 |newspaper=The Citizens' Voice |date=August 14, 2009}}</ref><ref name="dale-mericle">{{cite news |url=http://www.mcall.com/news/nationworld/state/all-a16_kickbacks.6988485aug14,0,250767.story |title=Luzerne builder latest to admit guilt in scandal |last=Dale |first=Maryclaire |date=August 14, 2009 |agency=Associated Press |newspaper=[[The Morning Call]] |accessdate=August 26, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090903004413/http://www.mcall.com/news/nationworld/state/all-a16_kickbacks.6988485aug14%2C0%2C250767.story |archivedate=September 3, 2009 |df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=United States v. Robert K. Mericle |url=http://www.usdoj.gov/usao/pam/Victim_Witness/Luzerne_County_Corruption/Mericle/mericle_index.html |website=The United States Attorney's Office, Middle District of Pennsylvania |accessdate=August 27, 2009}}</ref><ref name="mericle pleas">{{cite news |url=http://www.timesleader.com/news/Mericle_pleads_guilty_09-03-2009.html |title=Mericle pleads guilty |last=Morgan-Besecker |first=Terrie |date=September 3, 2009 |newspaper=Times Leader |accessdate=September 3, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090907090018/http://www.timesleader.com/news/Mericle_pleads_guilty_09-03-2009.html |archivedate=September 7, 2009}}</ref> Mericle was released from federal custody in 2015 after serving a one-year sentence.<ref>{{cite news |title=Robert Mericle released from federal prison |url=http://thetimes-tribune.com/news/robert-mericle-released-from-federal-prison-1.1873258 |accessdate=October 1, 2015 |newspaper=The Scranton Times-Tribune |date=April 30, 2015}}</ref>
Sandra Brulo, the former Deputy Director of Forensic Services for the Luzerne County Juvenile Probation Office, agreed to plead guilty in March 2009 to federal obstruction of justice. Those charges stemmed from actions Brulo took after she became aware she had been named in the federal civil action. Brulo backdated her recommendation of a placement she made concerning a juvenile defendant in September 2007, and changed her original recommendation of placement to probation.<ref>{{cite web |title=United States v. Sandra Bruno |url=http://www.usdoj.gov/usao/pam/Victim_Witness/Luzerne_County_Corruption/Brulo/brulo_index.html |website=The United States Attorney's Office, Middle District of Pennsylvania |accessdate=August 25, 2009}}</ref>
== Criminal verdicts and sentences == [[File:Mark Ciavarella.jpg|thumb|[[Mark Ciavarella]] booking photo]] On February 18, 2011, following a trial, a federal jury convicted Ciavarella on 12 of the 39 remaining counts he faced including racketeering, a crime in which prosecutors said the former judge used children "as pawns to enrich himself." In convicting Ciavarella of racketeering, the jury agreed with prosecutors that he and Conahan had taken an illegal payment of nearly $1 million from a youth center's builder, then hid the money.<ref name="philly20110218">{{cite news |title=Ex-judge Mark A. Ciavarella Jr. guilty in 'cash for kids' case |url=http://articles.philly.com/2011-02-19/news/28611757_1_worst-judicial-scandals-juvenile-law-center-ciavarella |newspaper=[[The Philadelphia Daily News]] |accessdate=February 21, 2011 |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726010623/http://articles.philly.com/2011-02-19/news/28611757_1_worst-judicial-scandals-juvenile-law-center-ciavarella |archive-date=July 26, 2011}}</ref>
The panel of six men and six women also found Ciavarella guilty of "honest services mail fraud" and of being a tax cheat, for failing to list that money and more on his annual public financial-disclosure forms and on four years of tax returns. In addition, they found him guilty of conspiring to launder money. The jurors acquitted Ciavarella of extortion and bribery in connection with $1.9 million that prosecutors said the judges extracted from the builder and owner of two youth centers, including allegations that Ciavarella shared the proceeds of FedEx boxes that were stuffed with tens of thousands of dollars in cash.
Following Ciavarella's conviction, he and his lawyer appeared on the steps of the courthouse to give an impromptu press conference. The press conference was interrupted by Sandy Fonzo, whose son Edward Kenzakoski committed suicide after Ciavarella adjudicated him to placement, despite Kenzakoski's first-time offender status.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.pennlive.com/midstate/index.ssf/2011/02/mom_blames_luzerne_county_judg.html |title=Mom blames son's suicide on Luzerne County judge in 'kids for cash' case |newspaper=[[The Patriot-News]] |accessdate=17 September 2014 |agency=Associated Press |date=February 22, 2011}}</ref>
On August 11, 2011, Ciavarella was sentenced to 28 years in federal prison as a result of his conviction.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://archive.boston.com/news/nation/articles/2011/08/12/pa_judge_gets_28_years_in_kids_for_cash_case/ |title=Ex-judge given 28-year sentence |last=Rubinkam |first=Michael |date=August 12, 2011 |agency=Associated Press |newspaper=[[The Boston Globe]] |access-date=September 14, 2018}}</ref> He is currently being held at the [[Federal Correctional Institution, Ashland]], a low-security federal prison in eastern Kentucky.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Halpin |first1=James |title=Ciavarella requests hearing in effort to get new trial |url=http://citizensvoice.com/news/ciavarella-requests-hearing-in-effort-to-get-new-trial-1.1907178 |newspaper=The Citizen's Voice |accessdate=December 15, 2015}}</ref> He is scheduled for release in 2035, when he will be 85 years old.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bop.gov/iloc2/InmateFinderServlet?Transaction=IDSearch&needingMoreList=false&IDType=IRN&IDNumber=15008-067&x=101&y=10 |title=Mark A. Ciavarella |website=Federal Bureau of Prisons |accessdate=July 8, 2012}}</ref> Ciavarella appealed his conviction to the Third Circuit and it was rejected on July 25, 2013.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://thetimes-tribune.com/news/court-denies-civarella-appeal-1.1525776 |title=Court Denies Ciavarella Appeal |date=July 25, 2013 |newspaper=The Scranton Times-Tribune |accessdate=September 17, 2014}}</ref>
However, Ciavarella has continued to appeal, contending that the Supreme Court's decision in the [[McDonnell v. United States|case]] of ex-Governor of Virginia [[Robert McDonnell]] narrowed the scope of the [[honest services fraud]] statute.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.nationallawjournal.com/legaltimes/id=1202794986404/Ciavarella-Wants-to-Use-McDonnell-in-Acquittal-Bid |title=Ciavarella Wants to Use 'McDonnell' in Acquittal Bid |last=D'Annunzio |first=P. J. |date=August 8, 2017 |journal=[[The Legal Intelligencer]] |access-date=August 9, 2017}}</ref> On January 9, 2018, federal judge [[Christopher C. Conner]] threw out Civarella's convictions for racketeering, conspiracy to commit racketeering, and conspiracy to commit money laundering. Conner upheld Civarella's contention that his attorneys failed to raise [[statute of limitations]] claims on those charges. He ordered a new trial on those counts, but allowed the honest services fraud convictions to stand.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://citizensvoice.com/news/judge-rules-in-ciavarella-s-favor-in-kids-for-cash-appeal-1.2288319 |title=Judge rules in Ciavarella's favor in kids-for-cash appeal |last=Halpin |first=James |newspaper=[[The Citizens' Voice]] |date=January 9, 2018}}</ref>
[[File:Conahan Michael mug shot.jpg|thumb|[[Michael Conahan]] booking photo]] On September 23, 2011, Conahan was sentenced to 17 and a half years in federal prison after pleading guilty to one count of [[racketeering]] [[Conspiracy (crime)|conspiracy]].<ref name="conahan-sentenced"/> {{as of|2018|February}}, he is currently being held at the security facility at the [[Federal Correctional Institution, Miami]] in [[Florida]]. He is scheduled for release in 2026, when he will be 74 years old.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bop.gov/iloc2/InmateFinderServlet?Transaction=IDSearch&needingMoreList=false&IDType=IRN&IDNumber=15009-067&x=86&y=15 |title=Michael T. Conahan |website=Federal Bureau of Prisons |accessdate=February 3, 2018}}</ref>
On November 4, 2011, Powell was sentenced to 18 months in federal prison after pleading guilty to failing to report a felony and being an accessory to tax conspiracy. He was incarcerated at the [[Federal Prison Camp, Pensacola]], a low-security facility in Florida, and was released from a halfway house on April 16, 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://m.thetimes-tribune.com/news/kids-for-cash-financier-powell-assigned-to-fla-prison-camp-1.1250164 |title=Kids-for-cash financier Powell assigned to Fla. prison camp |newspaper=The Scranton Times-Tribune |date=December 28, 2011 |accessdate=July 8, 2012 |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120426040445/http://m.thetimes-tribune.com/news/kids-for-cash-financier-powell-assigned-to-fla-prison-camp-1.1250164 |archive-date=April 26, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bop.gov/iloc2/InmateFinderServlet?Transaction=IDSearch&needingMoreList=false&IDType=IRN&IDNumber=15110-067&x=94&y=19 |title=Robert J. Powell |website=Federal Bureau of Prisons |accessdate=July 8, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://citizensvoice.com/news/powell-released-from-florida-halfway-house-1.1474217 |title=Powell released from Florida halfway house |newspaper=The Citizen's Voice |date=April 16, 2013 |accessdate=April 27, 2013 |dead-url=yes |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140529123431/http://citizensvoice.com/news/powell-released-from-florida-halfway-house-1.1474217 |archive-date=May 29, 2014}}</ref> On August 10, 2015, a judge approved a $4.75M settlement agreement for Powell, for having paid kickbacks related to the adjudication of at least 2,400 juveniles.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/news/nation/2015/08/12/judge-oks-settlement-kids-for-cash-center-owner/7ctcSjOuQY0B58ji48BAPI/story.html |title=Pennsylvania jail owner to pay youths $4.75m |date=August 13, 2015 |newspaper=The Boston Globe |access-date=September 14, 2018}}</ref>
Robert Mericle's sentencing in connection with his guilty plea for failing to report a felony was delayed pending his anticipated testimony in the bribery trial of former Congressman and Pennsylvania State Senator [[Raphael Musto]]. On November 23, 2010, a federal grand jury had issued a six-count indictment against Musto, charging him with accepting more than $28,000 from an unnamed company and individual in exchange for his help in obtaining grants and funding.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Morgan-Besecker |first=Terrie |title=Grand jury indicts Sen. Raphael Musto for allegedly accepting kickbacks |newspaper=[[Times Leader]] |date=November 23, 2010 |url=http://www.timesleader.com/news/Federal-grand-jury-issues-indictment-against-Sen-Raphael-Musto.html |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101124173808/http://www.timesleader.com/news/Federal-grand-jury-issues-indictment-against-Sen-Raphael-Musto.html |archivedate=November 24, 2010 |accessdate=April 28, 2018}}</ref> Musto denied any wrongdoing.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Mocarsky |first=Steve |title=Musto denies any wrongdoing |date=November 23, 2010 |url=http://www.timesleader.com/news/Musto-denies-any-wrongdoing.html |newspaper=Times Leader |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101124174212/http://www.timesleader.com/news/Musto-denies-any-wrongdoing.html |archivedate=November 24, 2010 |accessdate=April 28, 2018}}</ref> After Musto died on April 24, 2014,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/timesleader/obituary.aspx?n=senator-raphael-j-musto&pid=170795666 |title=Obituary: Senator Raphael J. Musto |newspaper=Times Leader |date=May 28, 2014 |accessdate=May 28, 2014}}</ref> Mericle was sentenced the next day to one year in prison by Senior District Judge Edwin M. Kosik. Mericle was ordered to pay a $250,000 fine and to report to the Federal Bureau of Prisons on May 14, 2014.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.fbi.gov/philadelphia/press-releases/2014/robert-mericle-sentenced-to-one-year-in-prison |title=Robert Mericle Sentenced to One Year in Prison |website=U.S. Attorney's Office |date=April 25, 2014 |accessdate=May 28, 2014}}</ref> He was released on May 29, 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bop.gov/inmateloc/ |title=Raphael J. Musto |website=Bureau of Prisons Inmate Locator}}</ref>
== Victim lawsuits == Acting under a rarely used power established in 1722 and reserved for extraordinary circumstances, known as "[[King's Bench jurisdiction]]",<ref name="aopc-kingsbench">{{cite web |url=http://www.courts.state.pa.us/NR/rdonlyres/96F816DA-D829-4485-960E-642C92E866E5/0/8395AOPCChiefCounselTestifiesonKingsBenchAuthorityasSafetyValve.pdf |title=AOPC Chief Counsel Testifies on "King's Bench" Authority as an Important Safety Valve |date=August 3, 1995 |website=Administrative Office of Pennsylvania Courts |accessdate=August 27, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/62TSIk5BI?url=http://www.courts.state.pa.us/NR/rdonlyres/96F816DA-D829-4485-960E-642C92E866E5/0/8395AOPCChiefCounselTestifiesonKingsBenchAuthorityasSafetyValve.pdf |archivedate=October 16, 2011}}</ref> the Pennsylvania Supreme Court appointed a [[special master]] on February 11, 2009, to review all juvenile cases handled by Ciavarella.<ref name="morgan-specialmaster">{{cite news |url=http://www.timesleader.com/news/hottopics/judges/Judge_picked_to_review_Ciavarella_juvenile_cases_02-11-2009.html |title=Judge picked to review Ciavarella juvenile cases |last=Morgan-Besecker |first=Terrie |date=February 12, 2009 |newspaper=Times Leader |accessdate=August 27, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090901150112/http://www.timesleader.com/news/hottopics/judges/Judge_picked_to_review_Ciavarella_juvenile_cases_02-11-2009.html |archivedate=September 1, 2009}}</ref> Senior Judge Arthur Grim of the [[Berks County, Pennsylvania|Berks County]] Court of Common Pleas was appointed special master and returned his findings in an interim report dated March 11, 2009. Grim recommended that all adjudications handed down by Civarella from 2003 to 2008 be vacated, and that the affected juveniles' records be expunged. He concluded that due to Civarella's disregard for the juveniles' constitutional rights, as well as the kickbacks, no one who appeared before Civarella in that period had a truly impartial hearing.<ref name="grim-interimreport">{{cite web |url=http://media.theweekender.com/documents/Grimm+initial+review.pdf |title=First Interim Report and Recommendations of the Special Master |last=Grim |first=Arthur |date=March 11, 2009 |website=Supreme Court of Pennsylvania |accessdate=August 27, 2009}}{{dead link |date=November 2012}}</ref> On March 26, 2009, the Supreme Court approved Grim's recommendations and ruled that Ciavarella had violated the constitutional rights of thousands of juveniles, and initially hundreds of juvenile adjudications were ordered overturned.<ref name="cbs-overturn">{{cite web |title=Court Tosses Convictions Of Corrupt Judge |date=March 26, 2009 |website=CBS News |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2009/03/26/national/main4895883.shtml |accessdate=May 2, 2009}}</ref><ref name="learnandes-overturn">{{cite news |url=http://www.timesleader.com/news/hottopics/judges/Juvenile_records_to_be_erased_03-27-2009.html |title=Juvenile records to be erased |last=Learn-Andes |first=Jennifer |date=March 27, 2009 |newspaper=Times Leader|accessdate=August 27, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090406154217/http://www.timesleader.com/news/hottopics/judges/Juvenile_records_to_be_erased_03-27-2009.html |archivedate=April 6, 2009}}</ref>
A [[class action]] lawsuit was filed by the Juvenile Law Center on behalf of the juveniles who were adjudicated delinquent by Ciavarella despite not being represented by counsel or advised of their rights. Besides naming Ciavarella and Conahan, the suit seeks damages under the civil portion of the [[Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act]] (RICO) against the judges' spouses and business associates, shell companies, youth center officials, and Luzerne County.<ref name="jlc-luzernesuit">{{cite web |title=Juvenile Law Center Files Federal Class Action Complaint on Behalf of Affected Luzerne County Children and Families |url=http://jlc.org/news/25/luzernelawsuit/ |website=Juvenile Law Center |date=February 26, 2009 |accessdate=August 26, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090901204605/http://jlc.org/news/25/luzernelawsuit/ |archive-date=September 1, 2009 |dead-url=yes |df=}}</ref><ref name="jlc-ammend">{{cite web |url=http://jlc.org/news/27/luzerneamended/ |title=Juvenile Law Center Adds Luzerne County as a Defendant in Federal Class Action Lawsuit |date=April 27, 2009 |website=Juvenile Law Center |accessdate=August 26, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090901204539/http://jlc.org/news/27/luzerneamended/ |archive-date=September 1, 2009 |dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> Three other federal lawsuits filed on behalf of the victims have been consolidated with the Juvenile Law Center lawsuit into a master class action.<ref name="consolidate">{{cite news |url=http://www.citizensvoice.com/news/attorneys_agree_to_a_consolidated_lawsuit_against_ciavarella_conahan?localLinksEnabled=false |title=Attorneys agree to a consolidated lawsuit against Ciavarella, Conahan |last=Sisak |first=Michael |date=June 11, 2009 |newspaper=The Citizen's Voice |accessdate=September 6, 2009}}{{dead link |date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> An amended master complaint was filed on August 28, 2009.<ref name="complaint">{{cite web |url=http://www.jlc.org/files/luzernecounty/Amended-Master-Complaint-August-27-09.pdf |title=Amended Master Complaint |date=August 27, 2009 |website=Juvenile Law Center |accessdate=September 9, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100921101722/http://jlc.org/files/luzernecounty/Amended-Master-Complaint-August-27-09.pdf |archivedate=September 21, 2010}}</ref>
In June 2010, an injunction was filed on behalf of PA Child Care, Western PA Child Care, and Mid Atlantic Youth Services, the companies that provided treatment programs at the youth centers, to prevent the ordered destruction of thousands of juvenile records on the grounds the records are needed for the defense's case.<ref name="PA">{{cite news |url=http://www.timesleader.com/news/hottopics/judges/Juvie_papers_rsquo__destruction_blocked_06-09-2010.html?searchterm=%26quot%3BPA+Child+care%26quot%3B |title=Juvie papers' destruction blocked |date=June 10, 2010 |newspaper=Times Leader |accessdate=July 2, 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120308123439/http://www.timesleader.com/news/hottopics/judges/Juvie_papers_rsquo__destruction_blocked_06-09-2010.html?searchterm=&quot%3BPA+Child+care&quot%3B |archive-date=March 8, 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=}}</ref>
On July 8, 2013, a three-judge panel of the [[Third Circuit Court of Appeals]] ruled in the case of Markel International Insurance Company v. Robert J. Powell, (his business partner) Gregory Zappala, et al., that the insurance company had no obligation to defend or indemnify the individuals or corporations involved, leaving the defendants liable for adverse judgments.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www2.ca3.uscourts.gov/opinarch/122016np.pdf |title=Opinion of the Court Nos. 12-2016, 12-2132 |date=June 28, 2013 |website=United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit |access-date=August 1, 2013}}</ref>
== Interbranch Commission on Juvenile Justice == In the aftermath of the federal charges and defendant pleas, the [[Pennsylvania General Assembly]] moved to create a commission to investigate the entire set of circumstances surrounding the miscarriage of justice in Luzerne County. Sponsored by [[Todd A. Eachus|Representative Todd Eachus]] of [[Butler Township, Luzerne County, Pennsylvania|Butler Township]] in Luzerne County, House Bill 1648<ref name="hb1648">{{cite web |url=http://www.legis.state.pa.us/CFDOCS/Legis/PN/Public/btCheck.cfm?txtType=HTM&sessYr=2009&sessInd=0&billBody=H&billTyp=B&billNbr=1648&pn=2294 |title=House Bill No. 1648 |date=June 25, 2009 |website=The Pennsylvania General Assembly |accessdate=August 26, 2009}}</ref> established the Interbranch Commission on Juvenile Justice in July 2009. The commission comprises 11 members, appointed from each branch of government in Pennsylvania, with four members chosen by the judiciary, four by the legislature and three by the governor.<ref name="rendell-ICJJ">{{cite web |url=http://news.prnewswire.com/DisplayReleaseContent.aspx?ACCT=ind_focus.story&STORY=/www/story/08-07-2009/0005074011&EDATE= |title=Governor Rendell Signs Bill Creating Commission to Probe Juvenile Justice System |date=August 7, 2009 |website=Pennsylvania Office of the Governor |accessdate=August 26, 2009 |df= |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090902182032/http://news.prnewswire.com/DisplayReleaseContent.aspx?ACCT=ind_focus.story&STORY=%2Fwww%2Fstory%2F08-07-2009%2F0005074011&EDATE= |dead-url=yes |archive-date=September 2, 2009}}</ref>
In signing the legislation on August 7, 2009, Governor [[Ed Rendell]] castigated Ciavarella and Conahan, saying they "violated the rights of as many as 6000 young people by denying them basic rights to counsel and handing down outrageously excessive sentences. The lives of these young people and their families were changed forever."<ref name="rendell-ICJJ" /> Scheduled to meet a minimum of once per month, the commission was organized to investigate the actions of and damages caused by the two judges and review the state of the Luzerne County courts left in the wake of their tenures.<ref name="swift-icjj">{{cite news |url=http://citizensvoice.com/news/juvenile_justice_commission_s_first_meeting_set_for_next_week |title=Juvenile justice commission's first meeting set for next week |last=Swift |first=Robert |date=August 21, 2009 |newspaper=The Citizen's Voice |accessdate=August 26, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090902065824/http://citizensvoice.com/news/juvenile_justice_commission_s_first_meeting_set_for_next_week |archivedate=September 2, 2009}}</ref><ref name="pahouse-icjj">{{cite web |url=http://www.pahouse.com/PR/122081709.asp |title=Democratic leaders name nationally recognized expert to Interbranch Commission on Juvenile Justice |date=August 17, 2009 |website=Pennsylvania House Democratic Caucus |accessdate=August 28, 2009}}</ref> The commission was given power of [[subpoena]] and was required to complete its work and report its recommendations and findings to the three branches of state government by May 31, 2010.<ref name="swift-icjj2">{{cite news |url=http://citizensvoice.com/news/rendell_to_sign_legislation_creating_corruption_commission |title=Rendell to sign legislation creating corruption commission |last=Swift |first=Robert |date=August 7, 2009 |newspaper=The Citizen's Voice |accessdate=August 26, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090902065920/http://citizensvoice.com/news/rendell_to_sign_legislation_creating_corruption_commission |archivedate=September 2, 2009}}</ref>
== In popular culture == The scandal was featured in ''[[Capitalism: A Love Story]]'', the 2009 documentary by [[Michael Moore]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.filmbuffonline.com/FBOLNewsreel/wordpress/2011/02/18/judge-featured-in-moores-capitalism-a-love-story-found-guilty-of-racketeering/ |title=Judge Featured In Moore's 'Capitalism: A Love Story' Found Guilty Of Racketeering |last=Drees |first=Rich |date=February 18, 2011 |website=Film Buff Online |access-date=February 6, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://vimeo.com/34656343 |title=The 'Kids for Cash' Scandal from 'Capitalism: A Love Story' |website=[[Vimeo]] |access-date=September 14, 2018}}</ref> A full-length documentary covering the scandal entitled ''[[Kids for Cash (2013 documentary)|Kids for Cash]]'' was released in February 2014,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2925642/ |title=Kids for Cash (2013) |work=IMDb |accessdate=September 17, 2014}}</ref> and has been favorably reviewed.<ref>{{cite web |last=Rickey |first=Carrie |url=http://www.phillymag.com/ticket/2014/02/04/horror-movie-kids-cash/ |title=Movie Review: Kids for Cash |website=Phillymag.com |date=February 4, 2014 |accessdate=May 1, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.democracynow.org/2014/2/4/kids_for_cash_inside_one_of |title=Kids For Cash: Inside One of the Nation's Most Shocking Juvenile Justice Scandals |website=[[Democracy Now!]] |date=February 4, 2014 |accessdate=May 1, 2014}}</ref> In April 2014, [[CNBC]]'s crime documentary series ''[[American Greed]]'' reported on the case.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://citizensvoice.com/news/cnbc-s-american-greed-will-feature-kids-for-cash-scandal-1.1614363 |title=CNBC's 'American Greed' will feature kids-for-cash scandal |newspaper=The Citizen's Voice |date=January 10, 2014 |accessdate=June 3, 2014}}</ref>
The scandal has also led to several portrayals in fictional works. The ''[[Law & Order: Special Victims Unit]]'' episode "[[Law & Order: Special Victims Unit (season 10)#ep222|Crush]]", the ''[[CSI: NY]]'' episode "Crossroads",<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.csifiles.com/content/2012/07/review-csi-new-york-crossroads/ |title=Review: CSI: New York — 'Crossroads' |last=Trongo |first=Rachel |date=2012 |website=CSI Files.com |access-date=September 14, 2018}}</ref> and an episode of ''[[The Good Wife]]'' featured corrupt judges sending children to private detention centers. An episode of ''[[Cold Case]]'' called "Jurisprudence" is loosely based on this event.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://pubrecord.org/nation/6340/ripped-headlines-greed-corruption/ |title=Ripped from the Headlines: Greed, Corruption, and Hate Crimes in Northeastern Pennsylvania |first=Walter |last=Brasch |newspaper=[[The Public Record (newspaper)|The Public Record]] |date=December 21, 2009 |accessdate=November 16, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://archives.timesleader.com/2009_12/2009_05_07_TV_show_mirrors_area_legal__headlines_-news.html |title=TV show mirrors area legal headlines |newspaper=Times Leader |date=May 7, 2009 |accessdate=November 16, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004223720/http://archives.timesleader.com/2009_12/2009_05_07_TV_show_mirrors_area_legal__headlines_-news.html |archive-date=October 4, 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Michael R. |last=Sisak |url=http://standardspeaker.com/news/county-judges-provide-tv-fodder-1.493436 |title=County judges provide TV fodder |newspaper=[[Standard-Speaker]] |date=December 17, 2009 |accessdate=November 16, 2012}}</ref> In 2015, crime fiction novelist Ace Atkins, using the nom de plume of the late Robert B. Parker, wrote ''Kickback'', which borrows heavily from this case, transposing it into a Boston suburb instead. An episode of ''[[Billions (TV series)|Billions]]'' called "Quality of Life" has a subplot inspired by the scandal in which a New York City judge sentences youths harshly for financial gain.<ref>{{cite web |first=Joshua |last=Alston |url=http://www.avclub.com/tvclub/bobby-buries-one-his-own-solid-empty-billions-234440 |title=Bobby buries one of his own in a solid but empty Billions |website=The AV Club |date=March 28, 2016 |accessdate=March 28, 2016}}</ref> The novel ''Corrupted'' by Lisa Scottoline includes the scandal, portraying characters in the book as victims of the scandal.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Scottoline |first=Lisa |date=2015 |title=Corrupted: A Rosato and DiNuzio Novel |publisher=St. Martin's Press}}</ref>
The scandal was featured in an April 2018 episode of ''Swindled'', a [[podcast]] dealing with [[white-collar crime]].<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://swindledpodcast.com/podcasts/season-1/episode-10-the-judges/ |title=The Judges |date=April 14, 2018 |website=Swindled Podcast |access-date=April 20, 2018}}</ref>
The 2017 drama-thriller film ''The Archer''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.imdb.com/title/tt5806646/ |title=The Archer |website=IMDb |accessdate=September 14, 2018}}</ref> is loosely based on the scandal and is set in the California and Utah mountains instead of Pennsylvania.

{{Infobox company | name = Kocowa TV | logo = Kocowa logo.png | logo_size = | type = [[Joint venture]] | founded = November 2016 | hq_location_country = United States | hq_location_city = [[Los Angeles]] | owner = Korea Content Platform | industry = Entertainment | products = {{flatlist| * [[Streaming media]] * [[Video on demand]] * [[Video on demand|Television on demand]] }} | services = {{flatlist| * [[Digital distribution]] * [[Media service provider]] }} | divisions = Online Video Streaming Service | website = {{URL|kocowa.com}} }}
'''Kocowa''' is an online video streaming website headquartered in Los Angeles as a joint venture between the 3 major Korean Broadcast Networks [[Korean Broadcasting System|KBS (Korean Broadcasting System)]], [[Munhwa Broadcasting Corporation|MBC (Munhwa Broadcasting Corporation)]] and [[Seoul Broadcasting System|SBS (Seoul Broadcasting System)]] to provide Korean TV programs outside South Korea.
A subsidiary of KCP (Korea Content Platform) the name Kocowa stands for Korean Content Wave<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2017/digital/news/korean-streaming-service-kocowa-us-1202502916/|title=Korean Broadcasters Launch U.S. Streaming Service, Taking on Warner Bros.’ DramaFever|last=Spangler|first=Todd|date=2017-07-24|work=Variety|access-date=2017-10-04|language=en-US}}</ref> launched on July 2017<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/streaming-media-platform-kocowa-launches-in-the-united-states-offering-access-to-korean-tv-programs-300492535.html|title=Streaming media platform Kocowa launches in the United States, offering access to Korean TV Programs|last=Kocowa|website=www.prnewswire.com|language=en|access-date=2017-10-04}}</ref> to become the centralized content broker for existing platforms [[Viki (website)|Viki]], [[OnDemandKorea]], and [[DramaFever]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.kcpglob.com/|title=kcpglob|website=kcpglob|access-date=2017-10-05}}</ref>
== History == Three major Korean Broadcast Networks [[Korean Broadcasting System|KBS (Korean Broadcasting System)]], [[Munhwa Broadcasting Corporation|MBC (Munhwa Broadcasting Corporation)]] and [[Seoul Broadcasting System|SBS (Seoul Broadcasting System)]] consolidated its efforts to distribute content globally due to the rising demand for Korean content across the globe. In July 2017, Kocowa launched its streaming services accessible via PC, mobile and tablet with plans to expand its streaming services to Smart TVs.
== Services == Kocowa streams a variety of Korean programs ranging from TV series such as [[School 2017]] and [[The King in Love]], variety shows [[Running Man (TV series)|Running Man]] and [[Infinite Challenge]], and K-pop music stages including [[Inkigayo]] and [[Music Bank World Tour]] up to six hours after being broadcast in Korea. To differ from its platform partners Kocowa plans to provide perks and access to exclusive content including the 2017 World Tour of popular K-POP artist [[G-Dragon]]. Unlike Viki's subtitling technology that crowd-sources subtitle translations under a Creative Commons license<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.viki.com/community|title=Community - Rakuten Viki|website=www.viki.com|language=en|access-date=2017-10-05}}</ref> Kocowa's content is translated and subtitled by a certified translation team. Content will be translated initially in English and exclusively consumed in the U.S. market with plans to expand to Spanish and French speaking countries.
== Business == Kocowa is a subscription based service offering a variety of plans from $0.99 per day, $6.99 per month or $69.99 annually that provides full access to its programing without ads within six hours after being broadcast in Korea. Those who opt for the advertising-based plan can access new content after 24 hours of its release. In August 2017, Viki announced the partnership with Kocowa which allows its Viki Pass Plus subscribers to have additional access to Kocowa contents without separate subscription on Kocowa<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://kdramakisses.com/2017/08/15/viki-partners-with-kocowa-to-offer-new-subscription-option-called-viki-pass-plus/|title=Viki Partners With KOCOWA to Offer New Subscription Option Called Viki Pass Plus|date=2017-08-15|work=Kdrama Kisses|access-date=2017-10-05|language=en-US}}</ref>

{{refimprove|date=November 2010}} [[Image:Leo Mechelin 1900.jpg|thumb|right|Leo Mechelin]] '''Leopold (Leo) Henrik Stanislaus Mechelin''' (24 November 1839 in [[Hamina]], Finland – 26 January 1914 in [[Helsinki]], Finland) was a [[Finland|Finnish]] professor, statesman, senator and [[Liberalism|liberal]] reformer. A leading defender of the [[autonomy]] of the [[Grand Duchy of Finland]], and of the rights of women and minorities, Mechelin's 1905–1908 government ("Mechelin's Senate") made Finland the first nation in the world with the [[Universal suffrage|universal right to vote]] and to be elected. During his period in office the freedom of [[freedom of expression|expression]], the [[freedom of press|press]], and of [[freedom of assembly|assembly]] were introduced.
==Career== He also founded the [[Liberal Party of Finland]] (1880–1885), wrote its program, was one of the founders of the Union Bank of Finland 1862 (now part of Nordea Bank) and co-founded the [[Nokia|Nokia Company]] (1871) with [[Fredrik Idestam]], was the first chairman of the [[town council]] of [[Helsinki]] (1875–1876 and 1892–1899) and an internationally respected expert on politology and member of peace movement. Emperor Alexander II ennobled Mechelin 1876.
Mechelin led the passive resistance in Finland during the [[Russification of Finland|first period of oppression]] (1899–1905) until and even after his banishment (1903), from which officials had to let him return as a member of parliament (House of Nobles) 1904, welcomed by a celebrating crowd of 10,000 people. In a secret meeting of the [[Kagaali]], Mechelin had written a petition against the draft of Finns to the Russian army, which collected almost 500,000 signatures. His coalition, the Constitutionals, managed to end the draft through boycott.
==Biography== [[File:Leo Mechelin Bust.jpg|thumb|left|150px|Leo Mechelin's bust in [[Helsinki]].]] Born in [[Hamina]] in 1839, the son of Gustaf Johan Mechelin and Amanda Gustava Costiander, Leo Mechelin studied at the [[University of Helsinki]], gaining his [[Bachelor's degree|Bachelor's]] and [[Master's degree|Master's]] degree's in [[Philosophy]] in 1860, a bachelor's degree in law in 1864, and a [[Licentiate (degree)|License]] and [[Doctorate]] in 1873.
As professor of jurisdiction and politology 1874-82, Mechelin had argued that the tsars were bound by the [[Swedish Constitution of 1772|old constitutional laws]] from the time of the [[Sweden|Swedish]] rule of Finland (before 1809), and hence affirmed that Finland was a separate, constitutional state, which the tsar could only rule by law, whereas in Russia he had absolute power. During the periods of oppression, the tsar tried to impose unconstitutional laws, which Mechelin opposed. The [[Russian Revolution of 1905|unrests in Russia]] and [[Finnish general strike of 1905|Finland]] (1905) finally compelled the tsar to comply with the [[November Manifesto]] written by Mechelin. This allowed Mechelin to form a government (1905–1908) and to transform Finland into what was in many respects the first [[liberal democracy]] (e.g., in [[New Zealand]] women already had the right to vote but not to be voted; in [[Australia]] only white people had those rights) in 1906. In 1907, the first universal elections to the one-chamber [[Parliament of Finland|parliament]] ("eduskunta") were held, and 19 of its 200 first members were women. However, the constitutionals of all parties did not obtain the majority of seats, and the tsar realised that he could carry on with the oppression, starting the [[Russification of Finland|second period of oppression]] (1908–1917). After Mechelin's death (in 1914), the two revolutions in Russia allowed Finland to declare its independence (1917) and Mechelin's younger co-workers were able to complete his work.
[[Nokia]], once a world-leading [[mobile phone]] corporation, was founded by Mechelin and his student days' roommate [[Fredrik Idestam]] as a [[forestry]] company.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.tn/books?id=HugmyrqibtwC&pg=PA271&dq=leo+mechelin+and+nokia&hl=fr&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwit75W7ydbVAhXGWBQKHe7YDoYQ6AEIKzAB#v=onepage&q=leo%20mechelin%20and%20nokia&f=false|title=Wireless Horizon: Strategy and Competition in the Worldwide Mobile Marketplace|last=Steinbock|first=Dan|date=2003|publisher=AMACOM Div American Mgmt Assn|isbn=9780814407141|language=en}}</ref> Later Mechelin's wish to expand into the electricity business was at first thwarted by Idestam's opposition, but Mechelin managed to convince most shareholders of his plans and became the company chairman (1898–1914), thus being able to realise his visions.
Mechelin was also active in [[civil society]] and President of the current [[University of Art and Design Helsinki]] and of the [[Finnish Art Society]]. As a politician he was always highly respected among all parties and citizens, although after the dissolution of the Liberal Party (1885) he never joined any other party.
Mechelin demanded peaceful [[nonviolent resistance]] and did not bend even during hard times.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://kansallisbiografia.fi/kansallisbiografia/henkilo/3553 | title = Mechelin, Leo (1839 - 1914) | author = Tapio Helen | date = 1997-09-16 | publisher = Biografiakeskus | access-date = 2017-12-11}}</ref>

{{Redirect|LED}} {{Distinguish|LCD}} {{Use American English|date=October 2015}} {{Use mdy dates|date=March 2013}} {{Infobox electronic component | name = Light-emitting diode | image = RBG-LED.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = Blue, green, and red LEDs in 5 mm diffused case | working_principle = [[Electroluminescence]] | invented = [[H. J. Round]] (1907){{cite web|url=http://www.myledpassion.com/History/hj-round.htm|title=HJ Round Started It All By Discovering Electroluminescence|website=www.myledpassion.com}}
[[Oleg Losev]] (1927){{cite news| url=http://holly.orc.soton.ac.uk/fileadmin/downloads/100_years_of_optoelectronics__2_.pdf| title=The life and times of the LED — a 100-year history| date=April 2007| agency=The Optoelectronics Research Centre, University of Southampton| accessdate=September 4, 2012| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120915034646/http://holly.orc.soton.ac.uk/fileadmin/downloads/100_years_of_optoelectronics__2_.pdf| archivedate=September 15, 2012| df=mdy-all}}
[[James R. Biard]] (1961)[http://www.freepatentsonline.com/3293513.pdf US Patent 3293513], "Semiconductor Radiant Diode", James R. Biard and Gary Pittman, Filed on Aug. 8th, 1962, Issued on Dec. 20th, 1966.
[[Nick Holonyak]] (1962){{cite news|url=http://web.mit.edu/invent/n-pressreleases/n-press-04LMP.html |title=Inventor of Long-Lasting, Low-Heat Light Source Awarded $500,000 Lemelson-MIT Prize for Invention |date=April 21, 2004 |agency=Massachusetts Institute of Technology |accessdate=December 21, 2011 |location=Washington, D.C. |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111009111042/http://web.mit.edu/invent/n-pressreleases/n-press-04LMP.html |archivedate=October 9, 2011 }} | first_produced = October 1962 | symbol = [[File:LED symbol.svg]] | pins = [[Anode]] and [[cathode]] }} [[File:LED, 5mm, green (en).svg|thumb|Parts of a conventional LED. The flat bottom surfaces of the anvil and post embedded inside the epoxy act as anchors, to prevent the conductors from being forcefully pulled out via mechanical strain or vibration.]] [[File:Surface mount LED close up image.png|thumb|Close up image of a surface mount LED]] [[File:Br20 1.jpg|thumb|alt=Modern LED [[Green retrofit|retrofit]] with E27 screw in base|A bulb-shaped modern retrofit [[LED lamp]] with aluminium [[heat sink]], a light [[Diffuser (optics)|diffusing]] dome and [[E27 screw]] base, using a built-in power supply working on [[mains voltage]]]] A '''light-emitting diode''' ('''LED''') is a two-[[Lead (electronics)|lead]] [[semiconductor]] [[light source]]. It is a [[p–n junction]] [[diode]] that emits light when activated. {{Cite dictionary |title=LED |encyclopedia=The American heritage science dictionary |year=2005 |publisher=[[Houghton Mifflin Company]] }} [https://dictionary.reference.com/browse/led led] and [http://www.thefreedictionary.com/LED LED]. When a suitable [[Electric current|current]] is applied to the leads,{{cite web|title=TI LED Lighting Solution Overview|url=http://www.ti.com/ww/mx/multimedia/webcasts/TI_AVNET_Webinar_LED_Driver_11-26-2010.pdf|page=4|author=Gomez, Daniel |publisher=Texas Microsystems}}{{cite conference|last=Steiger|first=S.|last2=Veprek|first2=R. G.|last3=Witzigmann|first3=B.|conference=2009 9th International Conference on Numerical Simulation of Optoelectronic Devices|title=tdkp/AQUA: Unified modelling of electroluminescence in nanostructures|date=September 2009|pages=73–74|doi=10.1109/NUSOD.2009.5297218}} [[electron]]s are able to recombine with [[electron hole]]s within the device, releasing energy in the form of [[photon]]s. This effect is called [[electroluminescence]], and the color of the light (corresponding to the energy of the photon) is determined by the energy [[band gap]] of the semiconductor. LEDs are typically small (less than 1 mm2) and integrated optical components may be used to shape the [[radiation pattern]].{{Cite journal|last=Moreno|first=Ivan|last2=Sun|first2=Ching-Cherng|date=2008-02-04|title=Modeling the radiation pattern of LEDs|journal=Optics Express|volume=16|issue=3|pages=1808–1819|doi=10.1364/oe.16.001808|bibcode=2008OExpr..16.1808M}} Appearing as practical electronic components in 1962, the earliest LEDs emitted low-intensity infrared light. Infrared LEDs are still frequently used as transmitting elements in remote-control circuits, such as those in remote controls for a wide variety of consumer electronics. The first visible-light LEDs were of low intensity and limited to red. Modern LEDs are available across the [[visible spectrum|visible]], [[ultraviolet]], and [[infrared]] wavelengths, with very high brightness. Early LEDs were often used as indicator lamps for electronic devices, replacing small incandescent bulbs. They were soon packaged into numeric readouts in the form of [[seven-segment display]]s and were commonly seen in digital clocks. Recent developments have produced LEDs suitable for environmental and task lighting. LEDs have led to new displays and sensors, while their high switching rates are useful in advanced communications technology. LEDs have many advantages over incandescent light sources, including lower energy consumption, longer lifetime, improved physical robustness, smaller size, and faster switching. Light-emitting diodes are used in applications as diverse as [[navigation light#Aviation navigation lights|aviation lighting]], [[automotive lighting#Light emitting diodes (LED)|automotive headlamps]], advertising, [[Lighting|general lighting]], [[traffic signal]]s, camera flashes, lighted wallpaper and medical devices.{{Cite book|pmid=18002450|doi= 10.1109/IEMBS.2007.4352784|year= 2007|last1= Peláez|first1= E. A|title= LED power reduction trade-offs for ambulatory pulse oximetry|journal=2007 29th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society|volume= 2007|pages= 2296–9|last2= Villegas|first2= E. R|isbn= 978-1-4244-0787-3}} They are also significantly more energy efficient and, arguably, have fewer environmental concerns linked to their disposal.{{cite web |url=https://www.epa.gov/cfl/cleaning-broken-cfl |title=Cleaning Up a Broken CFL |website=www.epa.gov |publisher=United States Environmental Protection Agency|date=2013-01-22 }}{{Cite journal |doi=10.24084/repqj11.399 |url=http://www.ufrgs.br/ldtm/publicacoes/Evaluation%20of%20Alternative%20Disposal%20and%20Replacement%20of%20Fluorescent%20Lamps.pdf |title=Evaluation of Alternative Disposal and Replacement of Fluorescent Lamps |journal=Renewable Energy and Power Quality Journal |pages=636–639 |year=2013 |last1=Carlesi |first1=F. |last2=Oliveira |first2=M.O. |last3=Ando Junior |first3=O.H. |last4=Neto |first4=J.M. |last5=Spacek |first5=A.D. |last6=Coelho |first6=V.L. |last7=Schaeffer |first7=L. |last8=Bordon |first8=H. |last9=Perrone |first9=O.E. |last10=Bretas |first10=A.S. }} Unlike a [[laser]], the color of light emitted from an LED is neither coherent nor monochromatic, but the spectrum is narrow with respect to human vision, and for most purposes the light from a simple diode element can be regarded as functionally monochromatic.{{Cite web|url=https://www.energy.gov/eere/ssl/led-basics|title=LED Basics {{!}} Department of Energy|website=www.energy.gov|language=en|access-date=2018-10-22}}{{cite web|url=https://optiwave.com/resources/applications-resources/optical-system-led-spectral-distribution/|title=LED Spectral Distribution|author= |website=optiwave.com |accessdate=20 June 2017|date=2013-07-25}} ==History== ===Discoveries and early devices=== [[File:SiC LED historic.jpg|thumb|Green electroluminescence from a point contact on a crystal of [[silicon carbide|SiC]] recreates [[H. J. Round|Round]]'s original experiment from 1907.]] [[Electroluminescence]] as a phenomenon was discovered in 1907 by the British experimenter [[H. J. Round]] of [[Marconi Company|Marconi Labs]], using a crystal of [[silicon carbide]] and a [[cat's-whisker detector]].{{Cite journal |author=Round, H. J. |year=1907 |title=A note on carborundum |journal=Electrical World |volume=19 |page=309 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TAZRAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA309#v=onepage&q&f=false}} {{cite web |url=http://www.jmargolin.com/history/trans.htm |author=Margolin J|website=jmargolin.com |title=''The Road to the Transistor''}} Russian inventor [[Oleg Losev]] reported creation of the first LED in 1927.{{cite journal|last1=Losev|first1=O. As noted by Kroemer{{cite journal |last1=Kroemer |first1=Herbert |title=The Double-Heterostructure Concept: How It Got Started |journal=Proceedings of the IEEE|date=Sep 16, 2013 |volume=101 |issue=10 |pages=2183–2187 |doi=10.1109/JPROC.2013.2274914}} Braunstein "…had set up a simple optical communications link: Music emerging from a record player was used via suitable electronics to modulate the forward current of a GaAs diode. We had a great deal of fun playing with this setup." This setup presaged the use of LEDs for optical communication applications. No ASD-TDR-63-281. On August 8, 1962, Biard and Pittman filed a patent titled "Semiconductor Radiant Diode" based on their findings, which described a zinc diffused [[p–n junction]] LED with a spaced [[cathode]] contact to allow for efficient emission of [[infrared light]] under [[forward bias]]. After establishing the priority of their work based on engineering notebooks predating submissions from [[G.E.]] Labs, [[RCA]] Research Labs, [[IBM]] Research Labs, [[Bell Labs]], and [[Lincoln Lab]] at [[MIT]], the [[United States Patent and Trademark Office|U.S. patent office]] issued the two inventors the patent for the GaAs infrared (IR) light-emitting diode (U.S. Patent [http://www.freepatentsonline.com/3293513.pdf US3293513]), the first practical LED. Immediately after filing the patent, [[Texas Instruments]] (TI) began a project to manufacture infrared diodes. In October 1962, TI announced the first commercial LED product (the SNX-100), which employed a pure GaAs crystal to emit a 890 nm light output. In October 1963, TI announced the first commercial hemispherical LED, the SNX-110.{{cite journal| title=One-watt GaAs p-n junction infrared source |author1=Carr, W. N. |author2=G. E. J.|issue=9|bibcode = 1976ApPhL..28..499P }} ===Initial commercial development=== The first commercial LEDs were commonly used as replacements for [[incandescence|incandescent]] and [[neon lamp|neon]] indicator lamps, and in [[seven-segment display]]s,{{cite journal | url=http://www.datamath.org/Display/Monsanto.htm | title=LEDs cast Monsanto in Unfamiliar Role | author=Rostky, George | journal=Electronic Engineering Times (EETimes) |date=March 1997 | issue=944}} first in expensive equipment such as laboratory and electronics test equipment, then later in such appliances as TVs, radios, telephones, calculators, as well as watches (see list of [[#Indicators and signs|signal uses]]). Until 1968, visible and infrared LEDs were extremely costly, in the order of [[United States dollar|US$]]200 per unit, and so had little practical use. The [[Monsanto Company]] was the first organization to mass-produce visible LEDs, using gallium arsenide phosphide (GaAsP) in 1968 to produce red LEDs suitable for indicators.{{Cite book|author=Schubert, E. Fred |title=Light-Emitting Diodes|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2003|chapter=1|isbn=978-0-8194-3956-7}} [[Hewlett-Packard]] (HP) introduced LEDs in 1968, initially using GaAsP supplied by Monsanto. These red LEDs were bright enough only for use as indicators, as the light output was not enough to illuminate an area. Readouts in calculators were so small that plastic lenses were built over each digit to make them legible. Later, other colors became widely available and appeared in appliances and equipment. In the 1970s commercially successful LED devices at less than five cents each were produced by Fairchild Optoelectronics. These devices employed compound semiconductor chips fabricated with the [[planar process]] invented by Dr. Jean Hoerni at [[Fairchild Semiconductor]].{{cite patent | title=Method of Manufacturing Semiconductor Devices |country=US |number=3025589 | author=Hoerni, J.A. |fdate=May 1, 1959 |gdate=Mar 20, 1962}}[http://www.google.com/patents/US3025589 Patent number: 3025589] Retrieved May 17, 2013 The combination of planar processing for chip fabrication and innovative packaging methods enabled the team at Fairchild led by optoelectronics pioneer Thomas Brandt to achieve the needed cost reductions.{{Cite news| author=Bausch, Jeffrey |title =The Long History of Light Emitting Diodes |url=http://www.electronicproducts.com/Optoelectronics/LEDs/The_long_history_of_light-emitting_diodes.aspx|publisher =Hearst Business Communications |date= December 2011 }} LED producers continue to use these methods.{{Cite journal |last1 = Park |first1 = S. -I. |last2 = Xiong |first2 = Y. |last3 = Kim |first3 = R. -H. |last4 = Elvikis |first4 = P. |last5 = Meitl |first5 = M. |last6 = Kim |first6 = D. -H. |last7 = Wu |first7 = J. |last8 = Yoon |first8 = J. |last9 = Yu |first9 = C. -J. |last10 = Liu |doi = 10.1126/science.1175690 |first10 = Z. |last11 = Huang |first11 = Y. |last12 = Hwang |first12 = K. -C. |last13 = Ferreira |first13 = P. |last14 = Li |first14 = X. |last15 = Choquette |first15 = K. |last16 = Rogers |first16 = J. Retrieved on 2018-07-31. ===White LEDs and the illumination breakthrough=== Even though white light can be created using individual red, green and blue LEDs, perhaps using a single SMD (Surface Mount Device) or through-hole RGB LED, this setup results in poor color rendering or CRI, due to the fact that virtually only 3 wavelengths of light are being emitted, so the attainment of high efficiency in blue LEDs was quickly followed by the development of the first [[#Phosphor-based LEDs|white LED]]. In this device a {{chem|Y|3|Al|5|O|12}}:Ce (known as "[[YAG]]") [[cerium]] doped phosphor coating on the emitter absorbs some of the blue emission and produces yellow light through [[fluorescence]]. The combination of that yellow with remaining blue light appears white to the eye. However, using different [[phosphor]]s (fluorescent materials) it also became possible to instead produce green and red light through fluorescence. The resulting mixture of red, green and blue is not only perceived by humans as white light but is superior for illumination in terms of [[color rendering]], whereas one cannot appreciate the color of red or green objects illuminated only by the yellow (and remaining blue) wavelengths from the YAG phosphor. [[File:Haitz-law.svg|thumb|upright=1.45|Illustration of [[Haitz's law]], showing improvement in light output per LED over time, with a logarithmic scale on the vertical axis]] The first white LEDs were expensive and inefficient. However, the light output of LEDs has increased [[exponential growth|exponentially]], with a doubling occurring approximately every 36 months since the 1960s (similar to [[Moore's law]]). The latest research and development has been propagated by Japanese manufacturers such as [[Panasonic]], [[Nichia]], etc. and later by Korean and Chinese factories and investment such as: [[Samsung]], [[Samsung|Solstice]], Kingsun, and countless others.[http://www.ledcornbulbs.com/LEDlightsapplication/List-of-Top-10-LED-light-manufacturer-in-China-19.html List of Top 10 LED light manufacturer in China]. Ledcornbulbs.com (2013-06-07). Retrieved on 2018-07-31. This trend is generally attributed to the parallel development of other semiconductor technologies and advances in optics{{Citation needed|date=December 2015}} and [[materials science]] and has been called [[Haitz's law]] after Dr. Roland Haitz.{{Cite journal|doi=10.1038/nphoton.2006.78|title=Haitz's law|year=2007|journal=[[Nature Photonics]]|volume=1|page=23|issue=1|bibcode = 2007NaPho...1...23. }} Light output and efficiency of blue and near-ultraviolet LEDs rose as the cost of reliable devices fell.
